attributes.title: Processing of acceleration by the hand and eye

q1.value: Predicting accelerating targets for ocular tracking and manual interception

q2.value: Philipp Kreyenmeier, Luca Kämmer, Jolande Fooken, Miriam Spering

q3.value: Accurate motion prediction is a critical ability for many daily tasks. For manual interception, when playing ball sports or swatting a fly, we need to accurately predict an object's motion trajectory in order hit it successfully. Accurate ocular tracking of an object's motion not only aids perception and prediction of the object's trajectory (Bennett et al., 2010; Spering et al., 2011) but also enhances manual interception (Fooken et al., 2016; de la Malla, 2017). In our natural environment, we often encounter objects that suddenly slow down or speed up. Yet, our ability to perceptually judge accelerations is relatively poor (Brouwer et al., 2002; Bennett & Benguigui, 2013; Mueller et al., 2017) and humans make systematic interception errors when hitting accelerating targets (Brenner et al., 2016; Brenner & Smeets 2009). In contrast, predictive eye velocity can reflect the trajectories of accelerating or decelerating targets but requires long presentations times (>200 ms; e.g., Bennett et. al., 2007; Benguigui & Bennett, 2010). Here we ask whether the eye and hand share the ability to predict the reappearance of accelerating or decelerating targets during manual interception. Specifically, we ask whether both eye and hand integrate information about target acceleration across similar or different time scales. To this end, we will conduct a comprehensive study comparing ocular tracking and manual interception to investigate whether the eye and hand can use acceleration to predict object motion in order to intercept it.

q4.value:
First, in line with studies showing that humans make systematic errors when intercepting accelerating targets, we hypothesize that participants intercept ahead of the target when it decelerates and behind the target when it accelerates. 
Second, previous studies showed that predictive ocular tracking can take target acceleration into account but requires long presentation times. We test whether eye and hand integrate target acceleration information across similar time scales. If both eye and hand share the ability the predict the paths of accelerating targets, we would expect that longer target presentation times similarly enhance the ability accurately track and intercept an accelerating target (leading to smaller systematic interception errors with longer presentation times).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In our experimental task, participants view and intercept a moving target on a computer monitor, while we record their eye and hand movements using an Eyelink 1000 (Tower Mount, SR Research, Osgoode, ON) and a 3D Guidance trakSTAR (Ascension Technology, Shelbourne, VT), respectively. After initial fixation (for a random time between 400-800 ms), the target moves with an initial velocity and a constant acceleration of -8, -4, 0, 4, or 8 m/s2 and is visible for either 200, 500, or 800 ms (presentation time) before it disappears behind an occluder (see figure). After occlusion, the target reappears for 100 ms. Participants are instructed to predict the time of reappearance of the target by performing a quick interceptive hand movement to hit the target on the screen. The occluder has a constant width and thus, occlusion times depend on the level of acceleration (800, 720, 670, 630, and 600 ms for accelerations of -8, -4, 0, 4, and 8 m/s2, respectively). Target start position and initial velocity are adjusted for each level of acceleration and presentation time so that target position and velocity at the moment of occlusion are the same for all trajectories. At the end of each trial participants receive visual feedback about their interception position and the target position at the moment of interception. Each participant performs all 15 (3 presentation times x 5 levels of acceleration) experimental conditions (within-subject design; 40 trials per condition). Target trajectories with 0 m/s2 acceleration serve as control conditions.

Prior to the experiment, participants will perform a single practice block (30 trials) in order to become familiar with the task and equipment. During the practice block, eye movements will not be recorded the target remains visible for the entire trajectory.

q9.value: Initial fixation time, presentation times and accelerations are randomized in each trial.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited by the study team through a recruitment flyer, which will be posted in buildings and public spaces on UBC campus, or through a recruitment flyer via the 'Paid Studies Participant List' run through the UBC Department of Psychology. Additionally, participants who have participated in previous (unrelated) experiments and have agreed to be contacted by e-mail for future experiments in our lab may be asked to participate. 	
This study includes adult subjects who are between 19 and 60 years of age and have normal or corrected-to-normal visual acuity (they may wear glasses or soft contact lenses) to be able to see the stimuli. Excluded are non-English speaking subjects, subjects with a history of neurological disease (such as multiple sclerosis, stroke, or trauma to the head, including a concussion within 12 months of the study), psychiatric disease (such as schizophrenia or depression), eye disease (such as strabismus or amblyopia), or have an implanted pacemaker or defibrillator (as this would interact with the magnetic hand tracker), subjects with visual acuity below 20/20 (assessed by a visual acuity chart in the laboratory), or subjects who fail to achieve accurate fixation to calibrate the eye tracker at the beginning of the experiment.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 16 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 18, assuming that not all participants will complete the entire experiment or that technical problems may lead to the exclusion of participants.

q14.value: The sample size was determined using an a priori power analysis in G*Power. First, we ensured that our sample size provides sufficient power to investigate systematic interception errors caused by target acceleration. According to the data from Brenner et al. (2016), a sample size of n = 5 is required to observe an effect with a power of 0.80 (alpha = 0.05). Second, we are interested whether – at least for the longest presentation time – the eye and hand are able to use acceleration in order to track and intercept the target. Bennett et al. (2007) reported a significant effect of acceleration on total eye displacement for their longest presentation time. We used the reported slope of their regression analysis to determine our sample size of n = 16 (power = 0.80; alpha = 0.05).

q15.value: Data collection will be stopped once complete data sets from 16 participants have been collected.

question.value:
1. Presentation time before occlusion (800, 500, 200 ms), 	
2. Level of acceleration (-8, -4, 0, 4, 8 m/s2)

For the analyses of manual interception, the main outcome variables are: a) interception error, b) hand movement latency, and c) peak hand velocity. For the analyses of eye movements, the main outcome variables are: a) pursuit gain (eye velocity relative to target velocity) before target occlusion, b) eye velocity after target occlusion, c) timing of the first saccade after occlusion, and d) timing of the last saccade before interception.
For all variables we will calculate each subject's mean across trials for each experimental condition.

To determine whether acceleration was used to predict the target trajectory for manual interception, regression analyses with factor acceleration will be performed on the main outcome variables separately for each presentation time. Additionally, we will perform 3x5 repeated-measures ANOVAs with presentation time and acceleration as within-subject factors. Post-hoc t-tests (two-sided) will be performed for pairwise comparisons.

q21.value: We will use an alpha level of 0.05 and will apply Bonferroni-corrections to account for multiple pairwise comparisons.

q22.value: Trials will be excluded if participants blinked before the end of the trial or if the interception position was not detected by the hand tracker. If >30% of trials of a single participant do not pass our exclusion criteria, the entire data set of this participant will be excluded from further analyses.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete the experiment or no valid trials were recorded for one or multiple conditions, the subjects will be excluded from the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that eye and hand movements are closely related in this task. We will thus explore correlations between eye and hand movements. Moreover, we will explore whether the different accelerations also affected hand movement trajectories.

attributes.title: Do Dr. Google and Health Apps Have (Comparable) Side Effects? An Experimental Study

summary.value: The study project is concerned with a comparison of the emotional (e.g. health anxiety), body-related and behavioural effects of a health-related internet search (Google) vs. a health app to find the causes of bodily symptoms. Here the programmed scripts for the three experimental conditions (google, health app, waiting control group) as well as the raw data were uploaded.

attributes.title: Social isolation and vocabulary development: insights from families with varying SES

q1.value: Social isolation and vocabulary development: insights from families with varying SES

q3.value: A convincing body of research has shown that shared book reading in early childhood promotes language development (O'Farrelly et al., 2018; Sénéchal and Young, 2008). Yet, families with low social economic status (SES) might provide less stimulating environment for language development to their children, as compared to families with high SES, as they have sparser access to books and engage less frequently in shared reading interactions (Kelly et al., 2011, Melhuish et al., 2008). For instance, it has been estimated, that by the age of 4 years, toddlers from low SES families have heard about 30 million less words than peers from higher SES families (Hart and Risley, 1995). The current longitudinal study aims to assess home activities and interactions that parents engage in with their 8 to 36-month-old infants during the period of coronavirus lockdown in Norway, and to examine their role in early vocabulary development of Norwegian infants across varying in SES-background families.

q4.value:
We expect that parents from lower SES backgrounds will engage less frequently in shared book reading activities and structured parent-infant interactions than parents from higher SES backgrounds. 
We hypothesise that infants in lower SES families might be exposed to TV/cartoons more than infants in higher SES families. 
We expect that infants growing up in lower SES families will have smaller gains in both receptive and expressive vocabulary sizes than infants growing up in higher SES families. 
We expect that the frequency of shared book reading will explain more variance in vocabulary size than the frequency of other child-parent activities (see Montag et al., 2015).
We predict that more frequent use of dialogue style in shared book reading will be related to larger gains in expressive vocabulary (Flack et al., 2015). 
We expect that more frequent exposure to TV/baby cartoons will be related to smaller gains in receptive vocabulary (cf Kuhl et al., 2003).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study has a regression design: we will examine whether family's SES, frequency of shared book reading, structured plays and TV/baby cartoons exposure modulate gains in receptive and expressive vocabulary sizes.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will contact, by the means of social media, Norwegian parents having infants from 8 and 36 months of age and will invite them to take part in the current longitudinal study by filling in a  questionnaire at Time - 1 (at the beginning of the home lockdown) and at Time - 2 (at the end of the lockdown period). The questionnaires are hosted on nettskjema.no. The questionnaires will include a language questionnaire (the Norwegian Communicative Development Inventory, Simonsen et al., 2014) and a family background questionnaire (that will include information about siblings' gender and age and family's SES). At Time 2, we will ask what type of activities did parents engage in with their child (and their frequency) during the quarantine period. The language questionnaire will provide us with an estimate of a child's vocabulary size at Time 1 and Time 2. The following child inclusion criteria will be used: a child was born at term or less than two weeks before term, a child did not have (or does not have) auditory or visual deficits, a child is exposed to no less than 90% of Norwegian.

q13.value: We will stop data collection as soon as coronavirus lockdown is finished in Norway. Given our previous research, we expect a 10-15% of response rate. We will aim to invite as many participants as possible.

question.value:
Our dependent variable is the total number of words that parents would have reported their child understands (between 8 and 18 months of age) and produces (between 8 and 36 months of age). The total number of words transformed to the percentile (adjusted for age and gender) will be used as the dependent variable in the analyses. 

Our predictors are: the frequency of shared book reading during the quarantine period; the frequency of structured child-parent interactions, the amount of exposure to TV/cartoons. If the sample size permits, for those infants whose parents engage in shared book reading, we will include the type of reading as a factor (more verbalisations and dialogue-type of reading should result in larger gains in vocabulary). 

Maternal education (varying from 0 - Grunnskole to 5 - PhD) will be used a proxy of SES and will be included as a predictor in the analyses. 

We will also count the number of days between T1 and T2 (Gap_days) and will include it as a co-variate in the analyses.

First, we will examine the number of participants and the distribution of the SES backgrounds across the 6 possible categories (coded as a continuous variable, varying from 0 - Grunnskole to 5 - PhD). If the distribution is not homogeneous and we have relatively few answers per category (less than 5), then we will recode the SES variable into a binary factor (low [from 0 to 2], and high [from 3 to 5]).

Then, we will examine the role of different activities parents have engaged in during the quarantine period and the gain score in the vocabulary size. Modality (receptive vs expressive) will be included as a factor for 8-18-month-old infants and Child will be included as a random variable. We also will model a possible interaction between Frequency_read and Modality (cf Karras et al, 2005).

We will also include Gap_days as a co-variate in the analyses, as we expect larger gains of more days have passed between Time 1 and Time 2. 
 Gains~Frequency_read+Frequency_interaction+Frequency_TV+Frequency_outdoor+Maternal_educ+Modality + Modality:Frequency_read+Gap_days+(1|Child), data=8_18_mo_data 

If the model does not converge, then the interaction term will be removed from the model and the analyses will be performed for each modality separately.

Second, we will perform similar analyses for the expressive vocabulary (modality will be removed). For this, we will merge data on expressive vocabulary from 8-18 and 19-36-months of age. 

Gains~Frequency_read+Frequency_interaction+Frequency_TV+Frequency_outdoor+Maternal_educ+Gap_days, data=8_36_mo_data
 
For those infants whose parents do engage in shared book reading, we will examine the role of type of reading and frequency of reading in each data sample.

Gains~Type_reading+Frequency_read+Maternal_educ+Gap_days

In a separate series of analyses, we will examine differences in everyday activities across families from different SES backgrounds. If the data permits (see above), then correlation analyses will be performed between Maternal_educ (6 categories, coded as a continuous variable) and the frequency of different activities during the lockdown period; if not, then a binary factor of SES will be used and then all the data will be split in two (families with high and families with low SES).

q20.value:
For each child, the vocabulary size in percentile at Time 1 will be subtracted from the vocabulary size at Time 2, separately for receptive and expressive modality. As a result, we will obtain two gain scores (one for receptive and one for expressive vocabulary) for 8 to 18 month-old infants and one gain score for 19 to 36-month-old infants. The gain scores will be used in the statistical analyses. 
If we observe that some infants have close-to-ceiling vocabulary size at Time 1, then we will standardise the vocabulary score at both times and a standardised measure of gains will be used in the analyses: (voc_std(T2)-voc_std(T1)).

q24.value:
In the exploratory analyses, we will examine the role of outdoor activities (type and frequency) in children's well-being and self-regulation. 
In addition, we will examine whether there are differences between those infants who already attended a kindergarten before the coronavirus outbreak and those who did not.

q25.value:
References
Flack, Z. M., Field, A. P., & Horst, J. S. (2018). The effects of shared storybook reading on word learning: A meta-analysis. Developmental Psychology, 54(7), 1334–1346. https://doi.org/10.1037/dev0000512
Hart, B., & Risley, T. R. (1995). Meaningful differences in the everyday experiences of young American children (Paul H. Brookes). 
Karrass, J., & Braungart-Rieker, J. M. (2005). Effects of shared parent–infant book reading on early language acquisition. Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology, 26(2), 133–148. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appdev.2004.12.003
Montag, J. L., Jones, M. N., & Smith, L. B. (2015). The words children hear: Picture books and the statistics for language learning. Psychological Science, 26(9), 1489–1496. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797615594361
O’Farrelly, C., Doyle, O., Victory, G., & Palamaro-Munsell, E. (2018). Shared reading in infancy and later development: Evidence from an early intervention. Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology, 54, 69–83. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appdev.2017.12.001
Kelly, Y., Sacker, A., Bono, E. D., Francesconi, M., & Marmot, M. (2011). What role for the home learning environment and parenting in reducing the socioeconomic gradient in child development? Findings from the Millennium Cohort Study. Archives of Disease in Childhood, 96(9), 832–837. https://doi.org/10.1136/adc.2010.195917
Kuhl, P. K., Tsao, F.-M., & Liu, H.-M. (2003). Foreign-language experience in infancy: Effects of short-term exposure and social interaction on phonetic learning. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 100(15), 9096–9101. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1532872100
Melhuish, E. C., Phan, M. B., Sylva, K., Sammons, P., Siraj‐Blatchford, I., & Taggart, B. (2008). Effects of the Home Learning Environment and Preschool Center Experience upon Literacy and Numeracy Development in Early Primary School. Journal of Social Issues, 64(1), 95–114. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1540-4560.2008.00550.x
Simonsen, H. G., Kristoffersen, K. E., Bleses, D., Wehberg, S., & Jørgensen, R. N. (2014). The Norwegian Communicative Development Inventories: Reliability, main developmental trends and gender differences. First Language, 34(1), 3–23.
Sénéchal, M., & Young, L. (2008). The Effect of Family Literacy Interventions on Children’s Acquisition of Reading From Kindergarten to Grade 3: A Meta-Analytic Review: Review of Educational Research. https://doi.org/10.3102/0034654308320319

Findings from the Millennium Cohort Study. Archives of Disease in Childhood, 96(9), 832–837. https://doi.org/10.1136/adc.2010.195917
Kuhl, P. K., Tsao, F.-M., & Liu, H.-M. (2003). Foreign-language experience in infancy: Effects of short-term exposure and social interaction on phonetic learning. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 100(15), 9096–9101. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1532872100
Melhuish, E. C., Phan, M. B., Sylva, K., Sammons, P., Siraj‐Blatchford, I., & Taggart, B. (2008). Effects of the Home Learning Environment and Preschool Center Experience upon Literacy and Numeracy Development in Early Primary School. Journal of Social Issues, 64(1), 95–114. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1540-4560.2008.00550.x
Simonsen, H. G., Kristoffersen, K. E., Bleses, D., Wehberg, S., & Jørgensen, R. N. (2014). The Norwegian Communicative Development Inventories: Reliability, main developmental trends and gender differences. First Language, 34(1), 3–23.
Sénéchal, M., & Young, L. (2008). The Effect of Family Literacy Interventions on Children’s Acquisition of Reading From Kindergarten to Grade 3: A Meta-Analytic Review: Review of Educational Research. https://doi.org/10.3102/0034654308320319
registration_responses.q8.question: The study has a regression design: we will examine whether family's SES, frequency of shared book reading, structured plays and TV/baby cartoons exposure modulate gains in receptive and expressive vocabulary sizes.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will contact, by the means of social media, Norwegian parents having infants from 8 and 36 months of age and will invite them to take part in the current longitudinal study by filling in a  questionnaire at Time - 1 (at the beginning of the home lockdown) and at Time - 2 (at the end of the lockdown period). The questionnaires are hosted on nettskjema.no. The questionnaires will include a language questionnaire (the Norwegian Communicative Development Inventory, Simonsen et al., 2014) and a family background questionnaire (that will include information about siblings' gender and age and family's SES). At Time 2, we will ask what type of activities did parents engage in with their child (and their frequency) during the quarantine period. The language questionnaire will provide us with an estimate of a child's vocabulary size at Time 1 and Time 2. The following child inclusion criteria will be used: a child was born at term or less than two weeks before term, a child did not have (or does not have) auditory or visual deficits, a child is exposed to no less than 90% of Norwegian.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Our dependent variable is the total number of words that parents would have reported their child understands (between 8 and 18 months of age) and produces (between 8 and 36 months of age). The total number of words transformed to the percentile (adjusted for age and gender) will be used as the dependent variable in the analyses. 

Our predictors are: the frequency of shared book reading during the quarantine period; the frequency of structured child-parent interactions, the amount of exposure to TV/cartoons. If the sample size permits, for those infants whose parents engage in shared book reading, we will include the type of reading as a factor (more verbalisations and dialogue-type of reading should result in larger gains in vocabulary). 

Maternal education (varying from 0 - Grunnskole to 5 - PhD) will be used a proxy of SES and will be included as a predictor in the analyses. 

We will also count the number of days between T1 and T2 (Gap_days) and will include it as a co-variate in the analyses.
registration_responses.q19.question:
First, we will examine the number of participants and the distribution of the SES backgrounds across the 6 possible categories (coded as a continuous variable, varying from 0 - Grunnskole to 5 - PhD). If the distribution is not homogeneous and we have relatively few answers per category (less than 5), then we will recode the SES variable into a binary factor (low [from 0 to 2], and high [from 3 to 5]).

Then, we will examine the role of different activities parents have engaged in during the quarantine period and the gain score in the vocabulary size. Modality (receptive vs expressive) will be included as a factor for 8-18-month-old infants and Child will be included as a random variable. We also will model a possible interaction between Frequency_read and Modality (cf Karras et al, 2005).

We will also include Gap_days as a co-variate in the analyses, as we expect larger gains of more days have passed between Time 1 and Time 2. 
 Gains~Frequency_read+Frequency_interaction+Frequency_TV+Frequency_outdoor+Maternal_educ+Modality + Modality:Frequency_read+Gap_days+(1|Child), data=8_18_mo_data 

If the model does not converge, then the interaction term will be removed from the model and the analyses will be performed for each modality separately.

Second, we will perform similar analyses for the expressive vocabulary (modality will be removed). For this, we will merge data on expressive vocabulary from 8-18 and 19-36-months of age. 

Gains~Frequency_read+Frequency_interaction+Frequency_TV+Frequency_outdoor+Maternal_educ+Gap_days, data=8_36_mo_data
 
For those infants whose parents do engage in shared book reading, we will examine the role of type of reading and frequency of reading in each data sample.

Gains~Type_reading+Frequency_read+Maternal_educ+Gap_days

In a separate series of analyses, we will examine differences in everyday activities across families from different SES backgrounds. If the data permits (see above), then correlation analyses will be performed between Maternal_educ (6 categories, coded as a continuous variable) and the frequency of different activities during the lockdown period; if not, then a binary factor of SES will be used and then all the data will be split in two (families with high and families with low SES).

attributes.title: Biased evaluations of doctors in Germany? The relationship between doctors' ethnicity, gender, and review site ratings

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Preregistration “Biased evaluations of physicians in Germany? The relationship between physicians’ ethnicity, gender, and review site ratings”

other.value:
We will use archival data. Accordingly, there is no classical data collection. The data set is already available. We did not conduct any analyses prior to pre-registration. 

Robustness checks will also include analyses with control variables such as membership status (i.e., whether physicians are premium members) and/or urbanization of administrative districts. 

For exploratory reasons, we will compare the overall ratings of the different disciplines. 
All additional analyses will explicitly be displayed as exploratory. 

References: 
Liebau, E., Humpert, A., & Scheiderheinze, K. (2018). Wie gut funktioniert das Onomastik-Verfahren? Ein Test am Beispiel des SOEP-Datensatzes [How well does the onomastic approach work? A test based on the SOEP dataset]. SOEPpapers on Multidisciplinary Panel Data Research. https://www.diw.de/documents/publikationen/73/diw_01.c.595744.de/diw_sp0976.pdf

sample.value: Sample size will be determined by the number of physicians with profiles on the review site (approximately 150,000 physicians).

analyses.value: Multilevel modelling (physicians nested in administrative districts and disciplines): cross-level interactions with within-level predictors migration background and gender as well as between-level predictors diversity, prosperity and gender distribution.

outliers.value: We do not expect relevant outliers. We will use the complete data set of medical physicians (including practitioners, specialists, and dentists). However, for robustness checks we will re-run analyses with data sets of physicians with a varying minimum amount of user-ratings.

dependent.value:
The main DV is the overall rating score on the review site. 
The review site provides ratings in five categories. A pretest (n = 247 physicians), however, indicates that these categories are highly correlated and form a reliable mean score ( = .987). Scores are based on the German grading system and can potentially range from 1 ‘very good’ to 6 ‘unsatisfactory’.

conditions.value:
There are no experimental conditions. The independent and moderating variables are:
1)	Migration background: A categorization regarding the existence of a migration background will be conducted based on physicians’ first and family names (Liebau, Humpert, & Schneiderheinze, 2018).
2)	Gender: Physicians’ gender is provided by the review site. 
3)	Diversity in administrative district: We use the percentage of foreigners living in a district as a proxy for ethnic diversity. 
4)	Prosperity in administrative district: We use the unemployment rate in a district as a proxy for prosperity. 
5)	Gender proportion in each discipline.

hypothesis.value:
The study uses archival data from a German physician review site. The main research question is whether physicians’ migration background (German without migration background vs. migration background) as well as their gender predict their overall rating score on the review site. 

H1: Physicians with a migration background receive worse ratings than German physicians without a migration background. 
H2: Female physicians receive worse ratings than male physicians.

We further study whether context factors in the administrative district (‘Landkreis’) in which physicians are located influence the relationship outlined in H1. 

H3a: The negative relationship between physicians’ migration background and their overall rating score is stronger in administrative districts with low diversity. 

H3b: The negative relationship between physicians’ migration background and their overall rating score is stronger in administrative districts with low prosperity. 

Finally, we investigate whether the gender distribution of physicians in the different disciplines (e.g., pediatrist, gynecologist, or urologist) predicts the rating of female vs. male physicians in the respective disciplines. 

H4: The relationship between physicians’ gender and their overall rating score is moderated by the ratio of men to women in their disciplines; thus female (male) physicians receive worse ratings, the lower the proportion of women (men) in their disciplines.

attributes.title: Generative and preventative causal learning in continuous time

q1.value: Base rate regularity in continuous time causal induction

q3.value: This study aims to explore whether and how people can make use of temporal information to learn generative and preventative causal connections in a continuous-time setting, under conditions where the effect has either a regular or a randomly timed base rate of activation.

q4.value: Based on past studies on inferring causal relationships under regular and irregular temporal delay conditions, we hypothesise that the accuracy of regular condition will be higher than the accuracy of irregular condition. Based on our previous study in this project, we hypothesise that people's performance will be above chance on average in the regular condition and positively correlated with our normative Bayesian inference model, while we are not sure whether these effects will obtain in the (harder) irregular setting.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Besides, within subjects, participants are blind to the ground truth (the true generative causal structure) in each learning problem.

question.value: We have a between-subject factor: base rate regularity (regular vs. irregular). Additionally, within subjects, participants must make judgments about 18 clips. These 18 clips constitute 3 (A connection: generative, non-causal, preventative) * 3 (B  connection: generative, non-causal, preventative) situations (see the figure below), with 2 clips in each situation. See the pdf below for our Latin-square counterbalance between different participants.

q9.value:
We use the Latin-square design in this experiment. By doing so, we firstly generate 18 stimulus seeds. Each seed contains several meta-information (e.g., the regular base rate activating time; the irregular base rate activating time; the activating time of A, B; the generation delay of each A or B events if A or B is a generative cause; the prevention window of each A or B events if A or B is a preventative cause). Each seed can generate 9 different stimuli under each condition (regular vs. irregular), resulting in 18 stimuli-sets totally under Latin-square design (see the pdf above). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions, and then assigned to one of nine stimuli-sets under the condition.

The on-screen position of A and B (above or below), and the order in which clicks cycle through response options (e.g., click once: generative, click twice: preventative, click three times: non-causal) will be randomised between participants. The order of 18 clips will be pseudorandomised between participants, with the constraint that two clips from the same causal connection pattern will not be presented sequentially.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk (HIT Approval Rate for all requester's HITs: greater than 90%;  Number of HITs Approved: greater than 100; Location: United States). Participants will be paid $1 for participation plus will receive a 3 cent bonus for each correctly judged connection (the maximum payment for completing the 18 devices is thus $1.08, and participants in our previous study gained an average bonus of $0.78). Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: We plan to recruit 180 participants, with 90 participants in each group.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .9 power to detect a medium effect size (d=.5) at the standard .05 alpha error probability (two tails) in comparing regular and irregular conditions, which gives a guide of 86 participants in each group. Besides, we recruit 90 participants in each group such that approximately 10 participants saw each stimulus.

q15.value: We plan to recruit from mechanical Turk in batches of 9 participants (so avoiding their higher fees for batches equal or larger than 10).  However, an inherent possibility of collecting data online is that some workers will hold onto a task and complete it later meaning we cannot always distinguish dropouts from delayed completes.  If this occurs we may end up with slightly greater number of participants than intended.  If this occurs, we will simply analyse this larger sample.

question.value:
As our previous study in this project, we manipulate the form of two potential causal relationships in each test “device” and correspondingly present a different event sequence in each trial clip. Each connection can be generative, non-causal, or preventative yielding 9 unique device types. The stimuli generation rules are introduced in Design Plan -> Randomization. The final stimuli groups are subject to the constraint that no two activations of the same component overlap, and no two stimuli under the same seed are identical to each other.

See the attached file for the meta information of 18 seeds.

We will record participants' answers (generative, preventative, or non-causal) for each of the two connections in each trial, and record the time at which they make these judgments (relative to each 20 second trial).  We will also collect participants' age in years, gender (male, female, prefer not to say, other), and self reports of their level of engagement and how difficult they found the task (both on scales from 1 to 10).

We will compute the mean accuracy for generative, preventative and non-connection judgments for each participant and use this to compare participants against chance performance, and compare participants in different groups (regular vs. irregular).

We will use hierarchical linear models and t-tests to analyze our results, comparing the accuracy between regular vs. irregular groups, as well as participants' accuracy against chance performance.

In our exploratory modelling, we plan to compare participant’s answers against a random responding baseline model, a normative Bayesian inference model, and one or several heuristic models. We will try to predict participants’ aggregate behaviour as well as individual levels.

See the attached html file for the algorithm of our initial normative Bayesian inference model and its predictions to each clip (no adding perceptual noise).

q21.value: We will use standard p less than or equal to 0.05 criteria for inferences in our primary analyses.  We will use maximum likelihood to compare computational models with no or equal numbers of fitted parameters.  We will use the Bayesian Information Criterion or held-out cross-validation to compare models that have different numbers of parameters.

q22.value: Participants must pass an instruction comprehension check in order to start our task and the task is financially incentivized so we do not anticipate many non-attentive participants.  However, we will exclude from analysis any participant who provides the same judgment for all connections, on the basis that this is strongly indicative of rushing through rather than engaging with the task.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete the task, their data will not be stored and we will not include them in our analyses.

q24.value: We will explore whether participants’ performance differ in different kinds of structures (e.g., GG, GP, GN, NG, NP,...), and different intervention orders (e.g., AAABBB, ABABAB,...), and potential interaction between these factors and base rate regularity. We will record participants’ self-report difficulty and engagement rating to the task and compare the difference between regular and irregular groups. We will record the time at which participants make their judgments within each trial. We will explore what evidence drives participants to confirm their beliefs and how participants' beliefs change dynamically.

attributes.title: Discerning Evidence Strength in Sexual Assault Liability Cases

q1.value: Discerning Evidence in Civil Sexual Assault Cases

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to test the role of cognitive biases on decision making in a legal context. People rely on heuristics, or shortcuts, when making decisions, which often aids efficiency of judgment but can introduce systematic error. In this project, we will test one tenet of an emerging theory for how and why cognitive biases affect people’s discernment of the strength of evidence.  In the context of the #MeToo movement, we’re focusing specifically on civil cases against powerful institutions in which a victim alleges sexual assault. This study will focus on confirmation bias, which is one type of heuristic that explains the tendency for people to favor and seek out information that confirms existing beliefs and expectations (Nickerson, 1998). Using a Latin square design with within-subjects design elements, this study will look at how confirmation bias influences decisions about whether an institution demonstrated negligence, and thus liability, in the way they responded to a sexual assault allegation within their institution. We will also measure a pre-existing attitude that may induce confirmation bias called rape myth acceptance, which has been shown to influence decisions in criminal sexual assault cases (Hammond, Berry, & Rodriguez, 2011).

q4.value:
1.	We predict a main effect of case strength on judgments on the case (e.g., verdict); such that participants overall will be able to discern between strong and weak cases, and vote liable/guilty vs not liable/not guilty accordingly. 
2.	We predict a main effect of confirmation bias; such that, for example, those who read a case favoring a liable verdict will be more likely to vote liable. 
3.	We predict an interaction between the strength of the case a participant reads and the confirmation bias they are exposed to prior to reading the case. Specifically, we expect the effect of confirmation bias to be more prominent in the neutral case strength condition when there is more ambiguity on what the "correct" verdict is. 
4.	We predict Rape Myth Acceptance (RMA) to be a possible predictor. People who more strongly endorse rape myths (have a higher RMA score) will be less likely to find the institution liable, regardless of the condition. Again, we expect this effect to be more prominent in the neutral case condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
This study will be a 3 (case strength: strong case vs. weak case vs. neutral case) x 3 (confirmation bias information: favoring a strong case vs. weak vs. control/no confirmation bias) mixed factor. Case strength will be within subjects. Participants will read all three possible case strength vignettes. 
The order in which they see the differing case strength and confirmation bias information conditions will be counterbalanced.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups determining the order in which they see the differing strength and confirmation bias conditions, using Qualtrics randomization to evenly assign them to one of the three groups.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: This project is partly informed based on results from previous pilot studies. While the current design will differ from the original study, we have used information gained from previous data collection to inform our hypotheses for this new study.

question.value:
Participants for the lay sample will be jury eligible citizens. These participants must be 18 years of age or older, be U.S. citizens, and have never been convicted of a felony. If a participant does not meet this criteria they will be excluded, because they would not be eligible for jury service. We will collect participants from Prolific Academic. These participants will be compensated $6.50 per hour that they spend completing the study. This is the base rate for Prolific Academic participants. 
We aim to eventually also collect participants for a Judge sample will be collected from various judicial organizations.

q13.value: We will collect a total of 300 participants.

q14.value: Performing a priori power analysis using G8Power, we estimated a total of 300 participants necessary to detect a 0.20 effect size, with .8 power and .05 error. We powered according to the more conservative between subjects element.

question.value:
We will manipulate the strength of the case they see. The three levels are: strong, weak, neutral. The strong case has evidence in favor of the institution being liable, weak has evidence in favor of a not liable verdict, and neutral acts as a control and provides no information in favor of either verdict. 
We will also manipulate the type of confirmation bias information, which will be embedded in a mock news article participants read prior to each case. The three levels are: strong, weak, and a control article. The strong confirmation bias article will favor attitudes towards viewing the institution as liable, whereas the weak confirmation bias will favor attitudes towards viewing the institution as not liable. The control confirmation bias article will contain no confirmation bias statements.

We will measure people's rape myth acceptance using the Updated Illinois Rape Myth Acceptance Scale (on a scale of 1-5). To make it more intuitive, with higher scores indicating higher rape myth acceptance we will reverse score the original scale (1 = "strongly disagree," 5 = "strongly agree").

The outcome variables we will measure are: liable/not liable verdict (measured dichotomously and on a scale of 1-7, 1 being "not at all liable", 7 being "very liable"), damage awards when applicable, and confidence in their decision (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being "not at all confident", 7 being "very confident"). We will also ask them questions related to their judgments on specific pieces of evidence/case facts they were presented with.

To analyze dichotomous verdicts I will use mixed effects logistic regression models.
To analyze liability rating on a 7-point scale I will perform a mixed effects ordinal regression.
This will be done for the interaction between the confirmation bias and case strength condition.

I will analyze the main effect of RMA on liability judgments using a linear model; and also as a possible interaction with case strength condition.

registration_responses.q1: Discerning Evidence in Civil Sexual Assault Cases
registration_responses.q3: The purpose of this study is to test the role of cognitive biases on decision making in a legal context. People rely on heuristics, or shortcuts, when making decisions, which often aids efficiency of judgment but can introduce systematic error. In this project, we will test one tenet of an emerging theory for how and why cognitive biases affect people’s discernment of the strength of evidence.  In the context of the #MeToo movement, we’re focusing specifically on civil cases against powerful institutions in which a victim alleges sexual assault. This study will focus on confirmation bias, which is one type of heuristic that explains the tendency for people to favor and seek out information that confirms existing beliefs and expectations (Nickerson, 1998). Using a Latin square design with within-subjects design elements, this study will look at how confirmation bias influences decisions about whether an institution demonstrated negligence, and thus liability, in the way they responded to a sexual assault allegation within their institution. We will also measure a pre-existing attitude that may induce confirmation bias called rape myth acceptance, which has been shown to influence decisions in criminal sexual assault cases (Hammond, Berry, & Rodriguez, 2011).
registration_responses.q4:
1.	We predict a main effect of case strength on judgments on the case (e.g., verdict); such that participants overall will be able to discern between strong and weak cases, and vote liable/guilty vs not liable/not guilty accordingly. 
2.	We predict a main effect of confirmation bias; such that, for example, those who read a case favoring a liable verdict will be more likely to vote liable. 
3.	We predict an interaction between the strength of the case a participant reads and the confirmation bias they are exposed to prior to reading the case. Specifically, we expect the effect of confirmation bias to be more prominent in the neutral case strength condition when there is more ambiguity on what the "correct" verdict is. 
4.	We predict Rape Myth Acceptance (RMA) to be a possible predictor. People who more strongly endorse rape myths (have a higher RMA score) will be less likely to find the institution liable, regardless of the condition. Again, we expect this effect to be more prominent in the neutral case condition.

registration_responses.q9: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups determining the order in which they see the differing strength and confirmation bias conditions, using Qualtrics randomization to evenly assign them to one of the three groups.

attributes.title: RWA and SDO and the COVID-19 pandemic

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
The Study will be made live on Saturday March 21st, and we will only collect data on March 21st.

We will also administer the conscientiousness subscale from the Big5 for exploratory purposes.

sample.value: 300 participants will be recruited through Amazon's Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value:
1. We will correlate RWA and SDO with all DVs listed above.
2. We will compute mediation models with Hayes' PROCESS MACRO in SPSS to determine whether beliefs about the coronavirus being a hoax mediates the relationships between RWA/SDO and the other DVs listed above.
3. We will ensure that the relationships identified in the analyses above hold after statistically controlling for both social and economic conservatism, age, income, and education level.

outliers.value: The study will end with an attention check question: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” Participants will select one of five answers: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will assured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses.

dependent.value:
We have the following DVs depending on the hypothesis:
1. To what extent have you been practicing social distancing in the past week in light of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic? (1 = not at all, 6 = a lot)
2. To what extent have you washing your hands with soap and water in the past week in response to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic? (1 = not at all, 6 = a lot)
3. To what extent do you believe that the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic is a hoax? (1 = definitely not a hoax, 6 = definitely a hoax).
4. As a free response, participants will list the solution(s) to the current coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic in the past week. We will count the number of solutions as a DV.
5. As a free response, participants will list the way(s) in which they have helped in response to the current coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic in the past week. We will count the number of helping behaviors as a DV.

hypothesis.value:
1. Do right wing authoritarianism (RWA) or social dominance orientation (SDO) predict whether people believe the COVID-19 pandemic is a hoax?
2. Do RWA or SDO predict helping behaviors in response to COVID-19?
3. Does belief that the COVID-19 pandemic is a hoax mediate the relationship between RWA/SDO and helping behaviors in response to COVID-19?

registration_responses.study_type_other: The Study will be made live on Saturday March 21st, and we will only collect data on March 21st.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: Based on a power analysis assuming a small effect, we target a sample of 400 people and therefore recruit 400 people on Prolific.ac.

analyses.value:
We will have three important variables:
1)The composite index forming the acceptance of policy as DV
2) A three-item measure of severity as the mediator (People's fear of the new coronavirus is exaggerated.; Without control measures, we will soon reach the capacity limit of our health care system, resulting in insufficient access to medical care for infected persons; Compared to related diseases such as the regular seasonal influenza, the death toll of the new coronavirus will be much worse.)
3) A measure of exponential growth bias as the IV. This measure is created by asking people about the development of a 100$ asset that grows 5% annually. Participants need to estimate the value after 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, and 30 years. Based on these values, we estimate the b term of the exponential function: ab^x, x being the number of years. The "b" value serves as the dependent variable. 

Then we will use a standard test of mediation (using the standard, boostrapped "process" procedure), as well as single regressions to show the effect of the IV on the MV, and the effect of the MV on the DV, the effect of the IV on the DV and the joint effect of the IV and MV on the DV. We will  in subsequent models control for various covariates (personally being infected, perceiving oneself as a riskperson, income, age, highest education, gender, general numeracy skills based on Gerardi et al., (PNAS), political ideology and religiousness.)

Importantly, we expect being a "riskperson" (pre-existing conditions, high age, etc.) to be strongly related to the MV and DV.

outliers.value: As our main IV is an open question assessing growth rates, it is very likely that we may observe highly "irrational" answers. Thus, we take care of this challenge by analyzing only truncated data and will delete the bottom and up 5% of the people in terms of their estimated growth factor (b). In addition, we will only include participants who correctly answer attention checks: Two such checks exist. One will ask people to enter 12345, and one will ask people to click the lower end of a answer in a question.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable is a composite index of the following items, which people answer on a five point scale (unreasonable to reasonable):

The government urges people to frequently wash their hands, use hand-sanitizer, and to refrain from touching one's face.
							
The government forbids public gatherings of more than 1,000 people (e.g., professional sport events, concerts, etc.).
							
The government shuts down all stores except grocery stores and pharmacies.
							
The government forbids all private gatherings of more than 5 people (e.g., private dinner parties, birthday parties, weddings, etc.).
							
The government requires that people's temperature is taken before entering a public building such as a grocery store.
							
						
The government requires citizens to work from their home-office where possible.
							
The government closes all borders in order to limit foreigners from affected countries entering the country (except holders of long-term visa, etc.).
							
The government grounds all flights and shuts down all train lines.
							
The government issues a shelter-in-place policy, disabling anybody from leaving their house except for collection of groceries and medication.
							
The government issues fines for violating any of the policies (e.g., $200 for being in public in a group of 5, etc.)
							
The government declares martial law, accompanied by temporally infringing the principles of "habeas corpus", thus enabling imprisonments without hearing or judicial oversight.
							
The government forces people to work in relevant industries (e.g., a company can be forced to produce desinfectant or to work as a caregiver in a hospital.)

conditions.value: none, as this is a purely correlational study.

hypothesis.value: We hypothesize that individual differences in exponential growth bias affect acceptance of coronavirus related-policy measuers and that this effect is mediated by perceived severity of an uncontrolled outbreak.
